title: Relates to clarifying the regulatory authority of the New York power authority over any municipality that owns and operates an electric distribution system
summary: Provides that the New York power authority shall have jurisdiction over any municipal corporation that owns and operates an electric distribution system and distributes any power from the authority.

BILL NUMBER:S2397

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the public authorities law and the general municipal law,
in relation to clarifying the
regulatory authority of the New York power authority

PURPOSE:
This act would clarify that the New York Power Authority retains
regulatory jurisdiction over all municipal electric utilities with
certain exceptions.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
Section 1 amends section 1014 of the public authorities law to clarify
that municipal electric utilities who purchase and distribute power
from the New York Power Authority shall be regulated by the Authority
and not by the Public Service Commission.

Section 2 amends section 364 of the general municipal law to exempt
from regulation by the Public Service commission those
municipalities who distribute power from the New York Power
Authority but do not generate power for distribution.

Section 3 sets forth the effective date of this Act.

EXISTING LAW:
Currently, Public Authorities Law section 1014 states that entities
whose power is generated exclusively by the New York Power Authority
shall be regulated by the Authority and not the Public Service
Commission. General Municipal Law section 364 provides that municipal
electric utilities shall be subject to the jurisdiction of the Public
Service Commission.

JUSTIFICATION:
Small municipalities across the state provide electric service to
their residents through electric distribution systems run by the
municipalities themselves. Pursuant to state and federal law, these
municipalities receive an allocation of low-cost hydropower from the
Niagara Power Project and through the New York Power Authority.
Before the deregulation of the power industry, these municipalities
purchased all of their power through the power Authority. After
deregulation, most municipalities now purchase a percentage of their
power on the open market.

As the law is written, this brings them under the regulatory
jurisdiction of the Public Service Commission. Accordingly, whenever
a municipality needs to change its rates, it must: expend hundreds of
thousands of dollars to hire experts and participate in a relatively
adversarial race-making process before the PSC. The PSC was created
to regulate the behavior of large, investor owned, for-profit utility

companies, and to hold them accountable to the public. Small
municipal utilities are already directly accountable to the public
through local elections. It is for this reason that similarly
situated utilities, such as rural cooperative electric utilities and
municipal water utilities, are not subjected to the PSC's regulatory
authority in this manner.

This legislation would restore the former state of affairs, where NYPA
regulated all the municipal electric utilities. NYPA already works
extensively with the municipal utilities because the vast majority of
their power comes from NYPA. Moreover, NYPA already regulates several
of the municipalities who still receive all of their power from NYPA.
However, this would have no effect on the Public Service Commission's
approval authority in regards to municipal utilities seeking to
exercise franchise rights to serve areas outside of their corporate
boundaries pursuant to section 68 of the Public Service law.

PRIOR LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
S7890-B of 2010 -Rules Committee

EFFECTIVE DATE:
January 1, 2012.
